subject: Cooking
title: Sound and Crunch: The Forgotten Flavor
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Sound and Crunch: The Forgotten Flavor.

hook.text: Pringles invested millions to engineer the perfect crunch sound. They knew sound sells chips.

buildup.text: Oxford researcher Charles Spence proved that louder crunch sounds make people rate chips as 15% fresher.

discovery.text: The auditory cortex contributes to flavor perception. Silence actually makes food taste stale.

twist.text: Airline food tastes bland partly because engine noise at 85 decibels suppresses taste perception by 30%.

climax.text: Some restaurants now design 'sonic seasoning' â€” playlists that enhance specific flavors in their dishes.

punchline.text: Crunch isn't texture. It's a flavor you hear.

quiz.question: How does loud background noise affect taste perception?
